title: Can a fact be true or false, or must it necessarily be true? - Quora

response.answer_text: Facts about the natural world are not necessarily true or false. Facts about the natural world are just propositions that you think should useful to others, independent of you as an observer. Mathematical facts can be true, with associated proof. A proposition is true if it is free of contradiction in its context. Definitions and axioms define the context. For example, I can state as a definition/axiom, "all things that are purple are greebles". If I then say, "this thing is purple", it follows logically that it is also a greeble. Unfortunately, I have no means for linking my perceptions to the natural world (i.e., reality). My brain could now be connected to a supercomputer that is feeding me synthesized perceptions--I cannot know otherwise. Thus, I cannot prove as true any proposition regarding the natural world. I can only present models of the natural world that I think are useful. It is possible that some people have Faith; i.e., the magical, transcendent ability to discern truths about reality. Unfortunately, you must have Faith to judge Faith. One apparent oddity about Faith is that for people who claim to have Faith, it appears not to provide any differentiated, useful models for prediction and control of the natural world. In that sense, it does not appear to be scientifically useful. Standard/conventional definitions of 'fact' commonly involve a degenerate, circular reference to 'true' (Definitions of fact - OneLook Dictionary Search Definitions of truth - OneLook Dictionary Search ); i.e., 'facts' are propositions that are true, and 'truth' is propositions that are factual.

Facts can be true or false, and need not be necessarily true. A visualization may help. Imagine a venn diagram of facts and anti-facts. The two circles should not intersect because they describe different things. The question is what is the boundary? Truth seems like a logical boundary... ...but, it's not because truth is absolute while facts are based on our observations. Consider the very common relativity thought experiment of a train being hit by lightning (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relativity_of_simultaneity). In this example two observers have two time-based facts that are true from their point of view, yet they are false from the other's point of view. Facts about systems that are not man-made are the observers' best guesses at the truth based on observations. There is observer bias by definition. Not all observers are right all the time.

How can a fact be false? A fact is merely a statement about reality that we believe to be true: Grass is greenBeijing is the capital of ChinaYou cannot turn base metals into GoldFacts may be based on the best available evidence and our best understanding of the underlying theory and mechanisms. Then someone comes along with some new evidence or a new theory that changes how we view the world, or at least some so-called facts about the world. Perhaps: A variety of grass that isn't greenA recent decision of the PolitburoNucleosynthesis in supernovaeAnd the facts change! Science is based upon a provisional understanding of the world. Facts are only facts based upon that provisional understanding. Even the most fundamental facts are subject to revision based on new evidence and new understanding. In science there is no absolute truth and "we don't know" is a perfectly acceptable answer. An irrefutable fact that is an absolute truth is a "red flag" to any scientist. Anyone claiming such knowledge can usually be safely ignored :-)

A fact is generally considered to be a proposition that is true. Propositions can be true or false. Consider proposition 1: objects fall to the earth in a vacuum at 9.8 m/s/s. That's generally considered a true proposition and so a fact. Proposition 2: There are no English sentences longer than 3 words. That's false because its self refuting and so wouldn't be considered a fact.  It's also important to distinguish between the truth and falsity of a proposition and an individual's knowledge of that proposition's truth value. Proposition 1 may true but it could have been the case that no one knows it's true. On empiricist and rationalist views, a proposition's truth value is unrelated to whether one knows of that truth value or not. This is not the case on postmodernist theories.

I think the issue here is that there are many false propositions which are believed (or have been) by many to be facts.  The problem is that belief does not confer factuality.  Scientists tend to avoid asserting propositions as facts because they are well aware that a more precise and more accurate proposition may come along.  Thus they tend to speak in terms of quantified accuracy and probability of correctness, not in terms of facts.  Folks who do speak of facts tend to do so carelessly and skepticism is normally justified.  It is only in the unearthly realm of mathematics that one can assert facts with absolute confidence.

A fact is a true proposition. From this it follows that necessarily all facts are true propositions. What does not follow is that all facts are necessarily true; that's a modal fallacy. To see this, consider the parallel case of bachelors: a bachelor is an unmarried man. From this it follows that necessarily all bachelors are unmarried men. What does not follow from this is that all bachelors are necessarily unmarried. And that's obvious, because my being a bachelor (like most facts) is contingent.

How can a fact be false? In the film, "Yellowbeard," (a farcical comedy by members of the Monty Python troupe, among others) Gilbert (Marty Feldman) tried to smuggle a woman aboard a British warship. Captain Hughes, (James Mason) the commander said, The theory that a woman on board a ship is bad luck, is now a proven scientific fact." Seriously, centuries ago much of what was accepted as fact was arrived at not by the scientific method, but by logic- largely uninformed logic at that. These conclusions arrived at by such haphazard methods were considered to be facts, until the scientific method proved most of them to be false.

Throughout my life, I have experienced many of my cherished facts being disputed.  Even now, we can experience many things that we accept as facts to become "non-facts".  My feeling is that the near further will bring more facts into question because there will be some very major changes on the horizon.  Look out because there will in all probability be big changes in western society.

A fact is an item of knowledge, that is, a true belief that we are justified in believing as true. So by definition, a fact cannot be false. If a fact that was thought to be true is later found to be false, it is no longer a fact.
In Math a axiom is a premise so evident as to be accepted as true without controversy.
